item.title: Arizona indicts Trump allies in 'fake elector' scheme; bird flu remnants found in milk
item.description: Arizona is now the fourth state to bring "fake elector" charges against Donald Trump's allies. Retail milk has tested positive for bird flu remnants. Here's what to know.

item.title: States find a downside to mandatory reporting laws meant to protect children
item.description: Colorado is looking at ways to weed out false reporting of child abuse and neglect as the number of reports reaches a record high. New York and California are reworking the policies, too.

item.title: American Airlines passenger alleges discrimination over use of first-class restroom
item.description: In a complaint to the airline, Pamela Hill-Veal, a retired judge, says that while on a Chicago-to-Phoenix flight, a flight attendant berated her and accused her of slamming the lavatory door.

item.title: Amazon warehouse workers in Alabama might get a third try at unionizing
item.description: Federal officials threw out the first vote, ruling that Amazon improperly interfered. The results of the second vote remain inconclusive. The federal government now determines what happens next.

item.title: He missed a chance to be the first Black astronaut. Now, at 90, he's going into space
item.description: Edward J. Dwight Jr. is set to be on the next Blue Origin rocket into space. The rare opportunity comes more than six decades after he was passed over to become a NASA astronaut.

item.title: Animals get stressed during eclipses. But not for the reason you think
item.description: After studying various species earlier this month, some scientists now say they understand the origin of animal behavior during solar eclipses.

item.title: The Supreme Court will hear Trump's claim he's immune from criminal prosecution
item.description: Trump's argument for immunity is broad: He contends that he cannot be prosecuted for his "official acts" as president unless he is first impeached, convicted by the Senate and removed from office.
item.content:encoded:

item.title: Coal and new gas power plants will have to meet climate pollution targets
item.description: Fifteen years after the EPA said greenhouse gasses are a danger to public health, the agency finalized rules to limit climate-warming pollution from existing coal and new gas power plants.
